item.title: New York Times Strands Hints and Answers for October 13, 2024
item.description:
Strands has yet another collection of challenging themed words all shuffled into a word-find grid. In order to win, you need to study the clue, figure out what the theme might be, and fill in all the words. While you'll know how many words you need to find, you won't know what they are ahead of time.

If you are stuck on this puzzle, check out all the helpful hints in the article below. There will be everything from theme hints that won't spoil any of the words to the full answer to this Strands for today.

The NYT Games Strands Puzzle #224 October 13, 2024

The Strands puzzle for today has the clue Time to Get Cozy . There are seven items to find: six themed words and a Spangram.

New York Times Games Strands Clues

If you are looking for help and already know how to play Strands , look at the clues in each of the sections below. Open each one to see what kind of theme hints are nestled inside.

General Hint 1

General Hint 2

General Hint 3

Spoilers for Two of the Words in Today's Strands

The two sections below contain a single spoiled word and a screenshot of where that word goes in this browser game. Open each one with the Read More button below it, but make sure you want spoilers before you open them up.

Spoiler 1

Spoiler 2

The Answer to Today's New York Times Games Strands

The answer to the New York Times Games Strands is in the expandable section below. If you open it up, you will find all the themed words, the Spangram, and a screenshot of where all those words go inside the letter grid. In order to open it up, you just need to press the Read More button below.

Today's Strands Explained

If an explanation of this minimalist puzzle game is what you need, open up the section below. This section will explain everything you need to know about how the theme, the words in the puzzle, and the clue fit together so it will all make sense.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Strands website, available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Dragon Ball: Sparking! ZERO Trophy Guide
item.description:
Including the platinum, there are 50 Trophies in Dragon Ball: Sparking! ZERO . Most of these can be obtained simply by playing through Episode Battle and completing the alternative objectives for Sparking Episode timelines, with the rest tied to some of the other game modes and title screen menus.

All of the Trophies in Dragon Ball: Sparking! ZERO are relatively easy to unlock once you understand the requirements to do so, although one or two of them require a fairly significant time investment. Still, for those desperate to unlock the platinum, this shouldn't be too much of an issue.

Dragon Ball Sparking! ZERO Achievement / Trophy Guide

Trophy Name / Description

Unlock Method

Sparking!

Unlock every other Trophy in Dragon Ball: Sparking! ZERO (PlayStation only).

Obtained all trophies.

A Taste of Victory

Win ten matches in any game mode.

Won 10 matches.

Winning Streak

Win 100 matches in any game mode.

Won 100 matches.

Encounter with New Rivals

Complete three online matches.

Fought in 3 Online Battles.

Connected Rivals

Complete 100 online matches.

Fought in 100 Online Battles.

Prepping For Battle

Change a character's outfit or assign an Ability Item via the Customize menu.

Customized a character.

Fated Confrontation

By recreating iconic encounters from the Dragon Ball manga and anime, players will be treated to special banter scenes at the beginning of the fight. They'll need to actually finish the fight for the scene to be counted towards their total.

Viewed 20 special Banter scenes.

A Flair for Fighting

Finish a battle using either Goku (Z - Mid) Super Saiyan's Angry Kamehameha, Master Roshi's Evil Containment Wave, or Goku (Z - End) Super Saiyan 3's Dragon Fist 20 times.

Viewed 20 Special Finishers.

World Tournament Champion

Start and complete the World Tournament using the World Tournament option of the Battle & Training menu.

Achieved victory in the World Tournament.

Cell Games Champion

Start and complete the Cell Games using the World Tournament option of the Battle & Training menu.

Achieved victory in the Cell Games.

Other World Tournament Master

Start and complete the Other World Tournament using the World Tournament option of the Battle & Training menu.

Achieved victory in the Other World Tournament.

Tournament of Destroyers Dominator

Start and complete the Tournament of Destroyers using the World Tournament option of the Battle & Training menu.

Achieved victory in the Tournament of Destroyers.

Tournament of Power Top Dog

Start and complete the Tournament of Power using the World Tournament option of the Battle & Training menu.

Achieved victory in the Tournament of Power.

I Can Never Get Enough!

Complete the main story of Goku's saga in Episode Battle mode.

Completed Goku's Saga.

Side by Side

Choose "Go it alone" in The Earth's Mightiest Duo?! and then defeat Raditz as quickly as possible in Raditz vs. The Turtle School.

Completed the "Side by Side" chapter of Goku's Saga.

Pushing the Limit

Choose "Work with Piccolo" in The Earth's Mightiest Duo?! and then defeat Raditz as quickly as possible in Rematch and Result.

Completed the "Pushing the Limit" chapter of Goku's Saga.

The Changing Future

Choose "Go and help" in Hyperbolic Time Chamber and then defeat Cell without getting hit by Solar Flare.

Completed the "The Changing Future" chapter of Goku's Saga.

Mind Your Own Business...

Complete the main story of Vegeta's saga in Episode Battle mode.

Completed Vegeta's Saga.

Parental Bond

Defeat Android 18 as quickly as possible in Wind-Up Doll and then defeat Super Trunks in Vegeta and Trunks.

Completed the "Parental Bond" chapter of Vegeta's Saga.

Number One Spot

Beat Trunks quickly without taking too much damage in Preparing for the World Tournament and then choose "Shake off brainwashing" in Vegeta's Wicked Heart.

Completed the "Number One Spot" chapter of Vegeta's Saga.

I'm Not a Kid Anymore!

Complete the main story of Gohan's saga in Episode Battle mode.

Completed Gohan's Saga.

The Strongest Warrior

Defeat the Frieza soldier and put up a good fight against Frieza in Defend Earth from the Frieza Force!

Completed the "The Strongest Warrior" chapter of Gohan's Saga.

Sorry to Keep You Waiting...

Complete the main story of Piccolo's saga in Episode Battle mode.

Completed Piccolo's Saga.

A Mentor's Guidance

Choose "Help out Goku" in Faint Unease.

Completed the "A Mentor's Guidance" chapter of Piccolo's Saga.

Mortal or God, I Won't Lose!

Complete the main story of Future Trunks' saga in Episode Battle mode. To unlock Future Trunks' saga, players will need to complete the Future Trunks arc of Goku's Saga.

Completed Future Trunks's Saga.

Shining Hope

Defeat Zamasu and Goku Black as quickly as possible in Twisted World.

Completed the "Shining Hope" chapter of Future Trunks's Saga.

Inherited Pride

Choose "Stay here and train" in Trunks's Choice and then defeat Gohan, Piccolo, and Vegeta as quickly as possible in To Become Strongest in the Universe. Next, choose "Follow Vegeta" in Father or Teamwork?

Completed the "Inherited Pride" chapter of Future Trunks's Saga.

Embarking toward Tomorrow

Choose "Stay here and train" in Trunks's Choice and then defeat Gohan, Piccolo, and Vegeta as quickly as possible in To Become Strongest in the Universe. Next, choose "Go with Gohan" in Father or Teamwork?

Completed the "Embarking toward Tomorrow" chapter of Future Trunks's Saga.

The Atrocious Emperor

Complete the main story of Frieza's saga in Episode Battle mode.

Completed Frieza's Saga.

Frieza Force Joins the Fray

Defeat Goku and Vegeta as quickly as possible in Frieza Revived and then complete all four branches of Frieza's Philosophy.

Completed the "Frieza Force Joins the Fray" chapter of Frieza's Saga.

Zero Mortal Plan

Complete the main story of Goku Black's saga in Episode Battle mode.

Completed Goku Black's Saga.

Proof of Justice

Defeat Goku and Vegeta as quickly as possible in Act Three Begins.

Completed the "Proof of Justice" chapter of Goku Black's Saga.

Strength Is Justice

Complete the main story of Jiren's saga in Episode Battle mode. To unlock Jiren's saga, players will need to complete the Universal Survival arc of Goku's Saga.

Completed Jiren's Saga.

True Strength

Choose "Wait and See" in Saiyan Rampage and then beat Frieza, Android 17, and Goku in Ultimate Climactic Battle after defeating Master Roshi.

Completed the "True Strength" chapter of Jiren's Saga.

The All-Knowing

Complete the main story for every playable character in Episode Battle mode.

Complete 21 Sagas in Episode Battle

Dream Battle

Complete 30 of the Bonus Battles found in the Custom Battle menu.

Completed 30 Bonus Battles.

Come forth, Shenron!

Players can get Shenron Dragon Balls by completing Whis's Wishes or by farming them in regular battles. After finding all seven, they can summon Shenron via the Come Forth... menu.

Summoned Shenron and had a wish granted.

Come forth, Porunga!

Players farm Porunga Dragon Balls by completing regular battles. After finding all seven, they can summon Porunga via the Come Forth... menu.

Summoned Porunga and had a wish granted.

Come forth, Super Shenron!

Players can get Super Shenron Dragon Balls by completing the main stories of Goku's saga, Future Trunks' saga, and Jiren's saga in Episode Battle mode. After doing so, they can summon Super Shenron via the Come Forth... menu.

Summoned Super Shenron and had a wish granted.

Rookie Warrior

Players can gain experience by completing battles or through Dragon Ball wishes.

Reached Player Level 5.

Seasoned Warrior

Players can gain experience by completing battles or through Dragon Ball wishes. Player Level 20 is the maximum level at the time of writing.

Reached Player Level 20.

Zenionnaire

Players can earn Zeni by completing battles or through Dragon Ball wishes.

Earned a total of 1,000,000 Zeni.

Big Spender

Players can spend Zeni by visiting the Shop via the main menu.

Spent a total of 1,000,000 Zeni.

A Little Something

Players can unlock Ability Items by completing Bonus Battles or buy them from the Shop. If they meet the unlock requirements for an Ability Item after purchasing it, their Zeni will be refunded.

Obtained 10 different Ability Items.

Ready for Anything

The shop will begin to stock more Ability Items as the player's Player Level increases.

Obtained 50 different Ability Items.

New Challengers

There are 47 unlockable characters in Dragon Ball: Sparking! ZERO . Players will need to unlock ten of them as part of New Challengers.

Unlocked 10 characters.

A Gathering of Rivals

Players will need to unlock 40 characters as part of A Gathering of Rivals. It's worth noting that alternate forms count towards this total, so unlocking Goku (GT) counts as four characters, and so on.

Unlocked 40 characters.

Showing Off

Players will need to set their favorite character, title (both icon and text), play time, favorite mode, favorite BGM, favorite stage, and background. It can be easy to forget to change the title text, as to do so, players will need to use the shoulder buttons while in the title icon menu.

Completely edited a Player Card.

Rookie Title Collector

Players will earn titles simply by playing the game. To claim them, they'll need to head to the Zen-Oh's Orders menu, where they can also check the requirements for some of the unlockable titles. It's also possible to use Dragon Balls to wish for extra titles.

Earned a title.

Title Collector

The fastest way to earn titles is by using characters in battle, as there's a title awarded for using each character once. With this in mind, players can just play 20 five-on-five matches using a completely different team each time and then claim the titles from the Zen-Oh's Orders menu.

Earned 100 titles.

item.title: 5 Dragon Ball Games With The Best Graphics
item.description:
The record-breaking Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero has rekindled a collective focus on the Dragon Ball franchise's impressive wealth of games, with many titles, though distinct, emulating that fast-paced, dynamic, and more than often chaotic sense of energy that has made the Dragon Ball so popular for decades.

Most of the best Dragon Ball games have received such recognition not just for their dynamic fighting mechanics, but how they're able to emulate Akira Toriyama's legendary style on top of the latest innovations in graphics. These games in particular do the best job of bringing top-tier graphics to the Dragon Ball universe.

5 Dragon Ball: The Breakers

Not A Lot Of Substance, But Plenty Of Style

Dragon Ball: The Breakers has quite a novel concept, but its execution has left fans wanting and, perhaps just as unfortunately, put the idea of this sort of game to bed for a very long time. In essence, Dragon Ball: The Breakers is a game that pits five ordinary people, with a power level probably in the single digits (but hey, power creep is a menace in this universe, they're probably actually Raditz tier) against a single, iconic villain from the Dragon Ball universe.

Much in the same vein as Dead by Daylight , this asymmetrical fighter does have some redeeming qualities in the graphical department, where it does a great job using high-end graphics and Toriyama's style to really evoke the menace and danger these heinous villains provoke when confronting ordinary civilians.

4 Dragon Ball: Xenoverse 2

An Amazing Fighter RPG Fusion

Before FighterZ, Dragon Ball: Xenoverse 2 was the preeminent fighting game, pitting a colossal variety of skills and characters from every series under the Dragon Ball umbrella. On top of this, there is an incredible character creator that lets people breathe life into almost any Dragon Ball OC they've ever concocted and has them take center stage in a fantastic wide-scale story. The game is still receiving DLC and updates and is an essential feature in any Dragon Ball fan's library.

The graphics in this game are stellar, with every fighter incredibly well modeled, and with fantastic, glitzy transformation sequences when they hit the next level of their power, it's a great feature in its own right and also helps the created character fit right in with the canon roster.

3 Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot

Explore Every Facet Of The Z Fighters

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot fuses fighting game mechanics with RPG elements, and then grafts on top of that some surprisingly deep slice-of-life elements that come together to make a fantastic title for those looking to explore and relive almost every part of the Dragon Ball Z anime and manga. Each character in the extensive roster can train, eat, relax, and, of course, battle across the setting of the major arcs, and they do all these things with incredible style.

Kakarot has bright, vivacious graphics that bring a new level of glamor and gloss not just to every character, but to the settings they inhabit as well - it all looks so idyllic and verdant, or ominous and dark, and it's a great way to complement the slower-paced sections of the game.

2 Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero

The Latest And Greatest 3D Dragon Ball Fighter

Dragon Ball: Sparking! Zero evokes that same kind of in-depth, detailed " oh my god how is this so good " energy that many longtime fans might not have felt since Budokai Tenkaichi 3 . This is an expansive story mode and an extremely fluid fighting game meshed together into the perfect Dragon Ball 3D fighter package. The inclusion of alternate character costumes and what-if scenarios borne from non-canon choices in the story mode makes for an even more detailed game.

The graphics in this title pop like nothing else, everything feels alive and bright, and each energy blast is articulated not just in a way where it looks good, but lands and explodes with a satisfying amount of weight.

1 Dragon Ball FighterZ

The Exemplar Among Anime Style Fighters

This game is crazy good. Stupidly good. Barring some interesting DLC practices, this might be the definitive 2D anime fighter, in no small part due to how much it just pops and shines in the graphical department. In most games, some less-than-stellar graphics can be made up for with a fantastic story or engaging mechanics, but Dragon Ball FighterZ draws players in with some stellar graphical fidelity, being more than just faithful to the anime's style, but elevating it with a unique video game flare that makes each battle shine with hyper-colored zeal.

The mechanics and graphics in this title go hand-in-hand to make each attack feel like it has weight behind it, and each battle feels destructive on a colossal scale. Everything from charging up ki moves to simple melee attacks has the appropriate amount of force and is articulated in such a fantastic "hyper-anime" style. No game feels quite as graphically vital as FighterZ.

item.title: Division 2: Best DPS & Armor PvP Build
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Best DPS & Armor PvP Build in Division 2
  • Division 2 Best AR DPS & Armor PvP Build Explanation

Having the right gear equipped on your character is essential in taking on PvP activities in Division 2 , and this high DPS & Armor AR build will help players do just that. Division 2 PvP can be daunting for many players for several reasons, including its sheer competitiveness. Still, it's an important aspect of the game, and players shouldn't avoid it.

Some great loot and essential farming methods are locked behind the Darkzone section. So, it's unfair for players to just stick to PvE activities and miss out on this exciting area. If you wish to stand on your own in a PvP fight against other players in Division 2 , this build will do wonders for you with a little practice.

Best DPS & Armor PvP Build in Division 2

The main star of this PvP build is the " Heartbreaker " brand set. This set works like a "Striker" brand set, but also grants you bonus armor. First and foremost, Heartbreaker provides players with the ability to pulse enemies on a headshot for 5 seconds . With this, hitting pulse enemies will grant players a stack of +1% weapon damage and +1% bonus armor for every hit on pulsed enemies (up to 50 stacks).

Stacking up armor increases your odds of survival in PvP, and having a ton of armor with bonus armor stacked on top of it will ensure your victory. However, landing those headshots is tricky for other players, and many will need some practice. So, here's the build breakdown showcasing all the gear you need to craft this build.

Gear Type

Gear Piece

Stats

Talents

Weapons

Named TKB-408 "Kingbreaker"

  • DMG: 123.4K
  • RPM: 650
  • MAG: 50

Perfect Flatline : +20% amplified weapon damage to pulsed enemies. It also pulses an enemy after 3 kills.

Eagle Bearer Assault Rifle (but you can use any AR)

  • DMG: 108.6K
  • RPM: 850
  • MAG: 60

Flatline or "Eagle's Strike" talent.

Mask

Heartbreaker Mask

  • Atr 1: Armor
  • Atr 2: Crit DMG
  • Mod: Crit Chance

None

Backpack

NinjaBike Messenger Backpack

  • Atr 1: Weapon DMG
  • Atr 2: Armor
  • Atr 3: Skill Tier
  • Mod: Crit Chance

Resourceful : It can slot into any gear set, unlocking their second gear set bonus too, with just one piece equipped.

Chest Piece

Fenris Chest Piece

  • Atr 1: Weapon DMG
  • Atr 2: Crit DMG
  • Atr 3: Crit Chance
  • Mod: Crit Chance

Unbreakable : When armor depletes, this talent restores your armor by 95% in PvE and 50% in PvP. It then goes on a cooldown for 60 seconds.

Gloves

Heartbreaker Gloves

  • Atr 1: Armor
  • Atr 2: Crit DMG

None

Holster

Named Brazos "Picaro's Holster"

  • Atr 1: Armor
  • Atr 2: Crit DMG
  • Atr 3: +15% Weapon DMG

None

Kneepads

Heartbreaker Kneepads

  • Atr 1: Armor
  • Atr 2: Crit DMG

None

Division 2 Best AR DPS & Armor PvP Build Explanation

This is a PvP build that relies on you landing headshots on enemy players. Landing the headshots will pulse them, activating the "Heartbreaker" brand set talent.

With every shot hit on the enemy, you'll stack weapon damage and armor on your character. With a ton of base armor, you'll be stacking a lot of bonus armor to survive intense PvP encounters. The longer you stay in a fight and land successful shots at enemy players, the greater your chances of winning the fight.

  • For DPS : Once enemies are pulsing, you'll be stacking up weapon damage plus the Perfect Flatline talent on the "Kingbreaker" will grant an additional 20% amplified damage. Despite its low fire rate, you'll be dishing out a ton of damage.
  • For Survivability : With the base armor reaching 1.7 million, it will scale the bonus armor received, significantly improving survivability. Even if your armor goes down, the Unbreakable talent on the chest piece will activate, giving you 50% armor (in PvP) back.

As a bonus tip, make sure to equip the Firewall Specialization to use its exclusive medkit, which heals your armor for 200% over time. Additionally, use the " Striker Shield ." Finally, have the pulse skill on your character to activate the brand set bonus at the start of the fight.

If you're new to the PvP content in Division 2 , rocking this build may not click at the first few encounters with other players. However, you'll gradually learn how to approach a fight and the right moment to attack, which will improve your gameplay a lot.

item.title: Best RPGs With Mysterious Worlds
item.description:
Role-playing games come in all shapes and sizes and, while some are better known for their moment-to-moment gameplay and/or build-crafting (ARPGs in the style of Diablo , for example), others are more often enjoyed for their intriguing worlds, open or not.

Games such as Dark Souls , while featuring innovative gameplay that spawned an entire genre, are known for their mysterious, often interconnected environments, most of which aim to confound the player at every turn. The lore that sprouts from these vaguely-painted worlds, the density of their secrets, the hidden nooks and crannies, and the labyrinthine design, all work together to provide an enigmatic atmosphere that's often incredibly memorable.

5 TUNIC

A Zelda-Inspired Adventure Built Around A Lack Of Information

This lightweight RPG/action-adventure game is practically built around its mysterious world, instantly creating a sense of mystery by depriving the player of key information. TUNIC is clearly inspired by older games in the Zelda franchise with its focus on lock-and-key exploration in condensed environments, but features elements of the Dark Souls series with its combat system, involving mechanics for dodging and parrying alike.

Much of TUNIC's enigmatic atmosphere is built from a lack of information right out of the gate, something that is supported mechanically through the in-game instruction manual. This manual's pages are scattered across the world, written in a mysterious language, and players are able to learn about the game, its systems, and its world, through collecting and studying these pages. The game's RPG mechanics are minimal, but players are able to level up their various stats using specific items found throughout the world. However, while the gameplay is rewarding and there are a variety of memorable boss fights, TUNIC's mysterious world is arguably its greatest strength.

4 Elden Ring

An Expansive World Packed With Secrets Waiting To Be Discovered

Elden Ring's world is ambitious, expansive, and packed with places to discover. From tucked-away caverns and dense forests to castled cities and sprawling underground dungeons, Elden Ring's mystery hinges on players experiencing the game with almost no prior knowledge of its lands. The expansive, secretive nature of the world offers up a mysterious atmosphere that rewards players with a sense of discovery at almost every turn, propelling players through its world and leading them from one place to the other with curious breadcrumbs.

In a lot of ways, Elden Ring is similar to the previous games of its developers, FromSoftware, but Elden Ring is markedly different from Dark Souls with the absence of a smaller, interconnected world. Elden Ring doesn't lock the player away in the same way Dark Souls does, and not nearly as often. Because of Elden Ring's massive scale and pure open-world, it's not nearly as easy to get lost, something that many fans of games such as the original Dark Souls may miss.

3 Lunacid

A First-Person RPG That Practices FromSoftware's Art Of Getting Lost

Lunacid is heavily influenced by older games developed by FromSoftware, before the advent of Dark Souls , when the now-iconic studio was still developing first-person dungeon crawlers such as Shadow Tower and King's Field . This horror-tinged ARPG is incredibly similar to the aforementioned titles, drenched in gloomy atmosphere and first-person dungeon-crawling action, interspersed with thoughtful and oftentimes labyrinthine exploration.

This action RPG's dark and gloomy fantasy world is smothered in fog and mystery, packed with memorable moments to experience, locations to be discovered, and characters to meet. The characters in particular, like Dark Souls , tend to be on the quirkier side, making for a welcome reprieve from the somber atmosphere.

2 Caves Of Qud

A Hand-Crafted, Utterly Strange, Retro-Futuristic World Complemented By Procedural Content

From the cozy and relatively safe town of Joppa and its friendly moisture farmers, and the towering Six Day Stilt, to the rusted caves of the dungeon Golgotha and the humble underground community at Grit Gate, the world of Caves Of Qud is diverse with strange and mysterious locations. There's an underlying sense of mystery to the atmosphere and setting as a whole, with the game taking place in a retro-futuristic world of sci-fi fantasy replete with ancient artifacts, cybernetics, and mutated creatures.

The careful balancing of hand-crafted and procedural content also allows Caves Of Qud to keep its sense of mystery for hours on end, extending across multiple playthroughs. The hand-crafted locations may become familiar over time, but the procedural wilderness and sprawling underground caves never lose their mysterious nature.

1 Dark Souls

A Dark, Atmospheric, Interconnected World With Mysterious Lore

The brutal difficulty and oppressive nature of this notorious ARPG is one thing, but the curiosity-inducing, atmospheric, and deeply mysterious world of Dark Souls is an important aspect of the game and helped a great deal in solidifying it as a modern classic. Dark Souls throws players in at the deep end, with very little preamble and even less explaining, dangling a mere handful of vague narrative threads to keep the player invested early on.

The vague nature of the game's narrative, its charismatic and often mysterious characters, and the sheer scale of its world all contribute to a setting dripping with mystery. There's a lot to discover in the kingdom of Lordran, and it's easy for players to get lost in its non-linear, labyrinthine world, making for an experience that offers a consistently mysterious atmosphere as players stumble down its many twisting paths.
